results.title: Stelarc: an interview at the N.T.U. Fine Arts Department, Darwin, Australia
results.creator_credit: Northern Territory University and Mary Jane Overall
results.brief_description: Stelarc is a unique performance artist, internationally renown for “events” he stages. In these, he suspends his nude body with fish hooks in various situations or uses a bionic arm and helmet which give him laser eyes. These live works of art, with the use of technology are shockingly magnificent in their audacity and innovation. This in-depth interview conducted in 1991, features footage and photographs from the various Stelarc “events”, and reveals the reasons and ideas behind them. Stelarc’s curiousity and vision have enabled him to make some unusual predicitions about the future of human kind.

results.title: Stelarc Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Stelarc Collection is the moving image archive of Australian performance artist Stelarc. The collection consists of documentation of events and performances throughout the career of the pioneering body artist from the 1970s to the 2000s. Renowned for pushing his body to its limits through durational performance, body modification and surgical enhancement, Stelarc has established a decades-long practice that explores the intersection between the human body and technology, proposing a post-human understanding of the world. This unique archive of video and photographic documentation spans the artist’s early hook suspensions and internal body probes to performances with a robotic third arm and experiments in virtual realities.

The collection is housed on a variety of formats used since the introduction of video in the 1970s, including reel-to-reel tape, VHS, U-Matic, SP Betacam and Mini DV. These variable formats are currently being digitised to ensure the preservation and legacy of the artist’s archive.

The Stelarc Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the artist through the Cultural Gifts Program.

results.title: Steffan the violin maker
results.creator_credit: Coronet Films, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Paul Saltzman
results.brief_description: Shows the painstaking process of violin making by focussing on sixteen year old Steffan Kellar, an apprentice violin maker and violinist living in West Germany. Highlights the beauty of the violin as a musical instrument, as well as indicating its cultural heritage.

results.title: Steering, wheels, front and rear axles
results.creator_credit: United States. Army. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Automotive Operation and Maintenance”.
How to check for play in the steering wheel and the front end assembly; correct wheel run-out; make a test; test springs, axles and overall back-lash.

results.title: Steering, gear changing and braking
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, John Edwards and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “How to Drive”.
Having got the feel of the car by practising starting and moving off procedures, the driver is now ready to increase speed. To attain this, demonstrates a system of steering, together with gear changing and braking techniques. While confidence and skill will grow, so too must the realisation that the safety of others is becoming increasingly dependent upon our actions and attitudes.

results.title: Steer 270
results.creator_credit: Brian Voce, Australia. Navy Office. Directorate of Public Relations and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description: Follows a task force made up of the ships Perth, Derwent and Supply, of the Royal Australian Navy on a good will cruise of Mauritius Island, Mombasa, Karachi, Singapore, and Sydney.

results.title: Steelworker
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams, Australian National Film Board and Hugh McInnes
results.brief_description: a steelworker relates his impression of life centred around the blast furnace of the Port Kembla district. He recalls the processes involved in steel making, mentions the number of ‘new’ Australians employed at the works, and tells of the facilities for recreation, entertainment and modern living provided by the principal city of the are, Wollongong.

results.title: Steeltown
results.creator_credit: Walford Hewitson, Wolf Koenig, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A portrait of Hamilton, the Pittsburgh or Birmingham of Canada. This is a rich and colorful subject that encourages imaginative treatment on the screen. The heart of the city is the immense complex of furnaces and rolling mills, but nearby are the lake, the mountain, and the rich fruit farms. How the work of the steel mills touches the city and its surroundings is shown in many views during both day and night.

results.title: Steel: A Glimpse of BHP's Newcastle steel works
results.brief_description: A brief look at the BHP steel plant in Newcastle. The film looks first at the smelting process and then concentrates on the rolling and cutting of steel into different shapes.

results.title: Steel saga
results.creator_credit: Broken Hill Proprietary Company and Neville Bletcher
results.brief_description: Studies the growth and development of Port Kembla to 1960. Shows all phases of the production of steel and looks at the lives and activities of the workers who produce the steel. Narrated by David Low, Brian Henderson, Wynne Nelson.
